title: How to Make a High Protein Vegetarian Breakfast

steps.headline: Combine your wet ingredients.
steps.description: First, melt your butter in the microwave or a small saucepan on the stovetop. Add the milk and maple syrup once melted. Whisk until everything is evenly mixed.

steps.headline: Mix your dry ingredients and combine with the wet ones.
steps.description: In a large mixing bowl, stir your buckwheat flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together until they are evenly combined. Pour in the wet ingredients and repeat. Add more milk if desired to thin the batter if it’s too thick for your taste.

steps.headline: Fold the egg white into the batter.
steps.description: First, crack the egg over the rim of a small bowl. Separate and discard the yolk before pouring the egg white into the bowl. Whisk the egg white with an electric mixer, then add it to your batter and fold it in.

steps.headline: Cook your pancakes in a skillet.
steps.description: Coat the bottom of a skillet with cooking oil or butter. Turn the heat to medium. Once the oil heats up, pour ¼ cup of batter (59 ml) into the skillet for each pancake. Let the bottom of each pancake cook until holes begin to break along its top. Flip the pancake over and cook the other side for roughly 15 to 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Drain your tofu.
steps.description: Layer a few sheets of paper towels on top of a plate. Remove the blocks of tofu from their packaging and water. Place them on the plate. Then press them to force out any excess water. With many tofu recipes, the more excess water you can get rid of, the better. However, since the tofu here is substituting eggs (which can be pretty moist), how much liquid you want to retain is entirely up to you. Alternately, you could use either a colander or wire rack in or over the sink instead of a plate and paper towels.

steps.headline: Prep your veggies and cilantro.
steps.description: For now, let the tofu continue to sit on the plate (or your wire rack or colander). While it drains some more, chop your onion into bite-size pieces. Do the same with your peppers. Then chop or tear up your cilantro leaves. If using paper towels and plate for your tofu, you may want to add some fresh towels before chopping your veggies if the originals have been soaked through.

steps.headline: Saute the veggies.
steps.description: Coat the bottom of a large skillet with your vegetable oil. Turn the heat to medium-high. Once the oil heats up, place the onion and peppers in the skillet. Saute for three or four minutes, stirring occasionally.

steps.headline: Add your coriander and cumin.
steps.description: Dump them on top of your veggies in the skillet. Then stir everything up until they coat the veggies evenly. Give them roughly a minute to cook, or until fragrant.

steps.headline: Add the tofu, turmeric, and beans.
steps.description: Break the tofu up into chunks and add them to the skillet. Mash the tofu into smaller pieces with your stirring spoon, then stir in the turmeric until the white tofu turns yellow. Add the beans and stir frequently while they cook. Remove from heat once everything is heated through. If the tofu has been drained pretty thoroughly, it should only take a couple of minutes to cook. If it still has a lot of water in it, you may want to cook it for longer so the excess moisture can reduce. If desired, mash the tofu up with a fork or potato masher in a bowl before adding it to the pan. But even “extra-firm” tofu is pretty soft, so mash it in the skillet with your stirring spoon if you want fewer dishes to wash.

steps.headline: Garnish, season, and serve.
steps.description: Add the cilantro to the skillet and stir it in. Do the same with salt and pepper as desired. Then serve right away while it’s still hot. Tofu scramble can be served as is with a plate or fork, or you can use it to make sandwiches or breakfast burritos. You can also garnish it further with scallions, avocado, cheese, and/or hot pepper sauce.

methods.name: Adding Seitan Bacon as a Side

steps.headline: Prep your oven and pan.
steps.description: First, turn the oven up to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). While that heats up, take a 9” x 5” (23 x 13 cm) loaf pan and line the inside with a sheet of aluminum foil. Then mist the foil with a nonstick cooking spray. You’re going to be making a seitan loaf, which will then be wrapped in the foil. So don’t worry about tucking or folding the edges of the foil over to the rim to secure it. Just make sure the bottom of the pan is totally covered.

steps.headline: Mix your dry ingredients.
steps.description: Place your wheat gluten in a large mixing bowl. Add your smoked paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, and 1 teaspoon of your smoked salt. Stir until they are evenly mixed.

steps.headline: Combine your wet ingredients.
steps.description: In a second mixing bowl, pour in your vegetable broth, vegetable oil, tamari, and ketchup. Then add 2 tablespoons of your liquid smoke and ¼ cup of maple syrup. Whisk until they’re combined evenly.

steps.headline: Make your dough.
steps.description: Pour your wet ingredients into the dry ones. Stir until thoroughly mixed. Then knead the dough for a few minutes, or until its consistency turns both uniform and smooth. If needed, transfer to a cutting board or similar surface to sculpt it into a loaf that will fit in your pan. It doesn’t need to be exact, but an ideal size for your loaf is 7 inches long, 4 wide, and 2 high (18 x 10 x 5 cm).

steps.headline: Glaze your dough.
steps.description: First, place your loaf in the pan. Then, in a mixing bowl, combine your ground black pepper with your remaining teaspoon of smoked salt, tablespoon of maple syrup, and 1.5 teaspoon of liquid smoke. Whisk until combined. Then pour the glaze over your dough and brush it over the top of your loaf, if needed, to cover it evenly.

steps.headline: Wrap your loaf.
steps.description: Fold the loose ends of the aluminum foil over your loaf. Seal it tightly. Make sure there aren’t any gaps where the liquid can escape. Prevent the glaze and juices from leaking, smoking, and burning.

steps.headline: Bake.
steps.description: Place the pan in the oven. Bake for 40 minutes. Then take the pan out and set it on a safe surface. Let it sit and cool until it is safe to touch.

steps.headline: Slice, saute, and serve.
steps.description: Once it’s cooled off, transfer the loaf to a cutting board. Slice it up into strips roughly ⅛-inch thick (0.3 cm). Coat the bottom of a large skillet with olive oil and turn the heat to medium. Once the oil heats up, place the strips in the skillet and saute each side for about 2 minutes, or until each turns crisp. Then enjoy.

tyn: Small saucepan, or microwave and microwave-safe bowl
text: Making Buckwheat Pancakes Combine your wet ingredients. First, melt your butter in the microwave or a small saucepan on the stovetop. Add the milk and maple syrup once melted. Whisk until everything is evenly mixed. Mix your dry ingredients and combine with the wet ones. In a large mixing bowl, stir your buckwheat flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together until they are evenly combined. Pour in the wet ingredients and repeat. Add more milk if desired to thin the batter if it’s too thick for your taste. Fold the egg white into the batter. First, crack the egg over the rim of a small bowl. Separate and discard the yolk before pouring the egg white into the bowl. Whisk the egg white with an electric mixer, then add it to your batter and fold it in. Cook your pancakes in a skillet. Coat the bottom of a skillet with cooking oil or butter. Turn the heat to medium. Once the oil heats up, pour ¼ cup of batter (59 ml) into the skillet for each pancake. Let the bottom of each pancake cook until holes begin to break along its top. Flip the pancake over and cook the other side for roughly 15 to 30 seconds. Scrambling Tofu with Black Beans Drain your tofu. Layer a few sheets of paper towels on top of a plate. Remove the blocks of tofu from their packaging and water. Place them on the plate. Then press them to force out any excess water. With many tofu recipes, the more excess water you can get rid of, the better. However, since the tofu here is substituting eggs (which can be pretty moist), how much liquid you want to retain is entirely up to you. Alternately, you could use either a colander or wire rack in or over the sink instead of a plate and paper towels. Prep your veggies and cilantro. For now, let the tofu continue to sit on the plate (or your wire rack or colander). While it drains some more, chop your onion into bite-size pieces. Do the same with your peppers. Then chop or tear up your cilantro leaves. If using paper towels and plate for your tofu, you may want to add some fresh towels before chopping your veggies if the originals have been soaked through. Saute the veggies. Coat the bottom of a large skillet with your vegetable oil. Turn the heat to medium-high. Once the oil heats up, place the onion and peppers in the skillet. Saute for three or four minutes, stirring occasionally. Add your coriander and cumin. Dump them on top of your veggies in the skillet. Then stir everything up until they coat the veggies evenly. Give them roughly a minute to cook, or until fragrant. Add the tofu, turmeric, and beans. Break the tofu up into chunks and add them to the skillet. Mash the tofu into smaller pieces with your stirring spoon, then stir in the turmeric until the white tofu turns yellow. Add the beans and stir frequently while they cook. Remove from heat once everything is heated through. If the tofu has been drained pretty thoroughly, it should only take a couple of minutes to cook. If it still has a lot of water in it, you may want to cook it for longer so the excess moisture can reduce. If desired, mash the tofu up with a fork or potato masher in a bowl before adding it to the pan. But even “extra-firm” tofu is pretty soft, so mash it in the skillet with your stirring spoon if you want fewer dishes to wash. Garnish, season, and serve. Add the cilantro to the skillet and stir it in. Do the same with salt and pepper as desired. Then serve right away while it’s still hot. Tofu scramble can be served as is with a plate or fork, or you can use it to make sandwiches or breakfast burritos. You can also garnish it further with scallions, avocado, cheese, and/or hot pepper sauce. Adding Seitan Bacon as a Side Prep your oven and pan. First, turn the oven up to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). While that heats up, take a 9” x 5” (23 x 13 cm) loaf pan and line the inside with a sheet of aluminum foil. Then mist the foil with a nonstick cooking spray. You’re going to be making a seitan loaf, which will then be wrapped in the foil. So don’t worry about tucking or folding the edges of the foil over to the rim to secure it. Just make sure the bottom of the pan is totally covered. Mix your dry ingredients. Place your wheat gluten in a large mixing bowl. Add your smoked paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, and 1 teaspoon of your smoked salt. Stir until they are evenly mixed. Combine your wet ingredients. In a second mixing bowl, pour in your vegetable broth, vegetable oil, tamari, and ketchup. Then add 2 tablespoons of your liquid smoke and ¼ cup of maple syrup. Whisk until they’re combined evenly. Make your dough. Pour your wet ingredients into the dry ones. Stir until thoroughly mixed. Then knead the dough for a few minutes, or until its consistency turns both uniform and smooth. If needed, transfer to a cutting board or similar surface to sculpt it into a loaf that will fit in your pan. It doesn’t need to be exact, but an ideal size for your loaf is 7 inches long, 4 wide, and 2 high (18 x 10 x 5 cm). Glaze your dough. First, place your loaf in the pan. Then, in a mixing bowl, combine your ground black pepper with your remaining teaspoon of smoked salt, tablespoon of maple syrup, and 1.5 teaspoon of liquid smoke. Whisk until combined. Then pour the glaze over your dough and brush it over the top of your loaf, if needed, to cover it evenly. Wrap your loaf. Fold the loose ends of the aluminum foil over your loaf. Seal it tightly. Make sure there aren’t any gaps where the liquid can escape. Prevent the glaze and juices from leaking, smoking, and burning. Bake. Place the pan in the oven. Bake for 40 minutes. Then take the pan out and set it on a safe surface. Let it sit and cool until it is safe to touch. Slice, saute, and serve. Once it’s cooled off, transfer the loaf to a cutting board. Slice it up into strips roughly ⅛-inch thick (0.3 cm). Coat the bottom of a large skillet with olive oil and turn the heat to medium. Once the oil heats up, place the strips in the skillet and saute each side for about 2 minutes, or until each turns crisp. Then enjoy. Finished.
sentences: Making Buckwheat Pancakes Combine your wet ingredients.
First, melt your butter in the microwave or a small saucepan on the stovetop.
Add the milk and maple syrup once melted.
Whisk until everything is evenly mixed.
Mix your dry ingredients and combine with the wet ones.
In a large mixing bowl, stir your buckwheat flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together until they are evenly combined.
Pour in the wet ingredients and repeat.
Add more milk if desired to thin the batter if it’s too thick for your taste.
Fold the egg white into the batter.
First, crack the egg over the rim of a small bowl.
Separate and discard the yolk before pouring the egg white into the bowl.
Whisk the egg white with an electric mixer, then add it to your batter and fold it in.
Cook your pancakes in a skillet.
Coat the bottom of a skillet with cooking oil or butter.
Turn the heat to medium.
Once the oil heats up, pour ¼ cup of batter (59 ml) into the skillet for each pancake.
Let the bottom of each pancake cook until holes begin to break along its top.
Flip the pancake over and cook the other side for roughly 15 to 30 seconds.
Scrambling Tofu with Black Beans Drain your tofu.
Layer a few sheets of paper towels on top of a plate.
Remove the blocks of tofu from their packaging and water.
Place them on the plate.
Then press them to force out any excess water.
With many tofu recipes, the more excess water you can get rid of, the better.
However, since the tofu here is substituting eggs (which can be pretty moist), how much liquid you want to retain is entirely up to you.
Alternately, you could use either a colander or wire rack in or over the sink instead of a plate and paper towels.
Prep your veggies and cilantro.
For now, let the tofu continue to sit on the plate (or your wire rack or colander).
While it drains some more, chop your onion into bite-size pieces.
Do the same with your peppers.
Then chop or tear up your cilantro leaves.
If using paper towels and plate for your tofu, you may want to add some fresh towels before chopping your veggies if the originals have been soaked through.
Saute the veggies.
Coat the bottom of a large skillet with your vegetable oil.
Turn the heat to medium-high.
Once the oil heats up, place the onion and peppers in the skillet.
Saute for three or four minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add your coriander and cumin.
Dump them on top of your veggies in the skillet.
Then stir everything up until they coat the veggies evenly.
Give them roughly a minute to cook, or until fragrant.
Add the tofu, turmeric, and beans.
Break the tofu up into chunks and add them to the skillet.
Mash the tofu into smaller pieces with your stirring spoon, then stir in the turmeric until the white tofu turns yellow.
Add the beans and stir frequently while they cook.
Remove from heat once everything is heated through.
If the tofu has been drained pretty thoroughly, it should only take a couple of minutes to cook.
If it still has a lot of water in it, you may want to cook it for longer so the excess moisture can reduce.
If desired, mash the tofu up with a fork or potato masher in a bowl before adding it to the pan.
But even “extra-firm” tofu is pretty soft, so mash it in the skillet with your stirring spoon if you want fewer dishes to wash. Garnish, season, and serve.
Add the cilantro to the skillet and stir it in.
Do the same with salt and pepper as desired.
Then serve right away while it’s still hot.
Tofu scramble can be served as is with a plate or fork, or you can use it to make sandwiches or breakfast burritos.
You can also garnish it further with scallions, avocado, cheese, and/or hot pepper sauce.
Adding Seitan Bacon as a Side Prep your oven and pan.
First, turn the oven up to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius).
While that heats up, take a 9” x 5” (23 x 13 cm) loaf pan and line the inside with a sheet of aluminum foil.
Then mist the foil with a nonstick cooking spray.
You’re going to be making a seitan loaf, which will then be wrapped in the foil.
So don’t worry about tucking or folding the edges of the foil over to the rim to secure it.
Just make sure the bottom of the pan is totally covered.
Mix your dry ingredients.
Place your wheat gluten in a large mixing bowl.
Add your smoked paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, and 1 teaspoon of your smoked salt.
Stir until they are evenly mixed.
Combine your wet ingredients.
In a second mixing bowl, pour in your vegetable broth, vegetable oil, tamari, and ketchup.
Then add 2 tablespoons of your liquid smoke and ¼ cup of maple syrup.
Whisk until they’re combined evenly.
Make your dough.
Pour your wet ingredients into the dry ones.
Stir until thoroughly mixed.
Then knead the dough for a few minutes, or until its consistency turns both uniform and smooth.
If needed, transfer to a cutting board or similar surface to sculpt it into a loaf that will fit in your pan.
It doesn’t need to be exact, but an ideal size for your loaf is 7 inches long, 4 wide, and 2 high (18 x 10 x 5 cm).
Glaze your dough.
First, place your loaf in the pan.
Then, in a mixing bowl, combine your ground black pepper with your remaining teaspoon of smoked salt, tablespoon of maple syrup, and 1.5 teaspoon of liquid smoke.
Whisk until combined.
Then pour the glaze over your dough and brush it over the top of your loaf, if needed, to cover it evenly.
Wrap your loaf.
Fold the loose ends of the aluminum foil over your loaf.
Seal it tightly.
Make sure there aren’t any gaps where the liquid can escape.
Prevent the glaze and juices from leaking, smoking, and burning.
Bake.
Place the pan in the oven.
Bake for 40 minutes.
Then take the pan out and set it on a safe surface.
Let it sit and cool until it is safe to touch.
Slice, saute, and serve.
Once it’s cooled off, transfer the loaf to a cutting board.
Slice it up into strips roughly ⅛-inch thick (0.3 cm).
Coat the bottom of a large skillet with olive oil and turn the heat to medium.
Once the oil heats up, place the strips in the skillet and saute each side for about 2 minutes, or until each turns crisp.
Then enjoy.
Finished.
